T1.label: Growth/Recovery
T1.description: Market re-rates on margin recovery and digital transformation
T1.plain_english: The evidence suggests Woolworths is in recovery mode. Margins are improving, digital sales are growing, and management is executing well on its transformation strategy.
T1.what_to_watch: Q3 FY26 margins and online penetration rate. If Australian Food EBIT margin holds above 5.5% and e-commerce grows >20% YoY, this narrative strengthens.
T1.upside: If digital transformation accelerates and margins expand further, the market could re-rate the stock to a premium multiple, driving 15-20% upside.
T1.risk_plain: If competition from ALDI and Costco intensifies faster than expected, margin recovery could stall.

T2.label: Managed/Base Case
T2.description: Defensive compounder delivering GDP+ growth with stable margins
T2.plain_english: Woolworths continues as a reliable, steady performer. Revenue grows roughly in line with the economy, margins stay stable, and the dividend keeps flowing. No fireworks, but no disasters either.
T2.what_to_watch: Revenue growth vs CPI inflation. If top-line growth consistently falls below inflation, the base case weakens.
T2.upside: Steady dividend growth and defensive positioning could attract capital in a risk-off market environment.
T2.risk_plain: If the economy slows significantly, even defensive names like Woolworths could see pressure on volumes.

T3.label: Risk/Downside
T3.description: Structural margin compression from competition and cost inflation
T3.plain_english: The worry here is that competition from ALDI, Costco, and Amazon is eating into Woolworths' market share and squeezing its profit margins. If costs keep rising faster than prices, profits shrink.
T3.what_to_watch: ALDI market share data and quarterly cost inflation trends. If ALDI share exceeds 12% nationally, this narrative gains weight.
T3.risk_plain: If ALDI continues to grow at current rates, Woolworths' margins will come under sustained pressure, potentially leading to earnings downgrades.

T4.label: Disruption
T4.description: Business model disruption from ALDI/Costco/Amazon Fresh
T4.plain_english: This is the worst-case scenario: a new competitor like Amazon Fresh launches in Australia and fundamentally changes how people buy groceries, making Woolworths' store network a liability rather than an asset.
T4.what_to_watch: Amazon Fresh AU launch timeline and any announcements of new international grocery entrants to the Australian market.
T4.risk_plain: If Amazon Fresh launches in Australian metro areas, it could trigger a structural re-rating of the entire sector.

big_picture: Woolworths is Australia's largest supermarket chain, with around 37% market share. The company is currently in a recovery phase after a period of competitive pressure, with improving margins and a growing digital business.

last_flip.trigger: H1 FY26 earnings beat +6% vs consensus; margin guidance upgrade

narrative_history.trigger: Q1 sales growth below expectations; competitive intensity rising

evidence_items.summary: H1 FY26 NPAT beat consensus by 6%; raised FY26 margin guidance
Online sales +22% YoY; Everyday Market GMV doubling
ALDI national grocery share steady at 10.2%; growth rate moderating from prior years
Management guided FY26 Australian Food EBIT margin to 5.8-6.0%, up from 5.5% in FY25
